bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, November 9, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] discusses an alleged case of yellow fever. He believes that a quarantine should be instituted for safety's sake.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, November 9, 1922
div1.opener:
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
November 9, 1922.
Dr. Wickliffe Rose,
General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
In reply to your letter, received this morning, I would say
that I had already received from the Bureau Dr. Lombard's report
of September 18th. on the alleged case of yellow fever aboard the
American schooner Burnham at Mobile Quarantine.

There is no question that from a quarantine standpoint the
case must be considered yellow fever. The rule there is to con-
sider for quarantine purposes all cases as yellow fever unless we
know they are not.

From a pathological standpoint, however, it is not so clear.
Very evidently neither the clinical history nor the autopsy were
made by one familiar with yellow fever. They are less definitive
therefor than had the contrary been the case.

That the onset of the fever was 14 days after leaving Paramaibo
does not in the least militate against the diagnosis of yellow fever--
simply against yellow fever contracted ashore. Death on the 7th.
day is a point in favor of positive diagnosis as is, possibly, the
the
apparent improvement on the 3rd. The malaise a few days prior to the
onset of the fever is, to some extent, against it.

The autopsy is very doubtful. The appearance of the liver as
described is in favor of a positive diagnosis, but the description is
so incomplete that it is by no means determinative. Clear, highly al-
buminous urine is the same, and probably of at least as much weight,
probably of more weight than the liver.

If there were no black vomit in the stomach--unless he had vomited
it just before death--and if punctate hemmorrhages were not seen, I
think yellow fever would be negatived, in spite of the two points I
have mentioned. The spleen is what one would expect to find in a death
from malaria. There is little change from normal in this organ in
yellow fever, certainly not on the 7th day

If I were sure that no lesions existed save those reported--i. e.
that there were no discolored spots on the body: no stains of black
vomit about the mouth: that the liver was not firm and bloodless on
section: that the kidneys were not both congested and yellow: that
there were no signs of hemorrhage into the stomach or duodenum I would
be inclined to negative the diagnosis of yellow fever, spite of the
highly albuminurious, clear urine. Taking into consideration, however,
that what is not mentioned is not always absent and that possibly the
reporter did not know quite what points to look for,
I feel like saying that the probability of its being yellow fever
is about 40%--that of its not bein, of course, 60%. If it was yellow
fever, iwhether plasmodia were found or not, it was complicated with
malarial infection. The spleen described could mean nothing else.

From a quarantine standpoint it was--as I have said--yellow fever
and it was right to treat it as such.
